request_pathways.name: Patient Request / Authorization to Use and/or Disclose Protected Health Information (English)
Solicitud del Paciente / Autorización para usar o revelar información médica protegida (Spanish)

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient downloads a generic HIPAA authorization form (English or Spanish), prints and hand-fills it, and submits via fax, mail, or in person; an electronic request option via Sharecare/HDS is also available.

red_flags: No differentiation between patient access and third-party release — patients requesting their own records are funneled through a generic authorization form designed for third-party disclosures
Vague fee notice ('*fees may apply') with no schedule, amounts, or reference to HIPAA cost-based limits for patient access
bright_spots: Fully translated Spanish-language form available alongside English version
Email offered as a delivery method for records — uncommon among facilities
Granular record type selection with 11 checkboxes plus write-in options
Visit exclusion option (Section 7) allows patients to omit specific dates of service
Practical 'until fulfilled' expiration option suited to one-time access requests

findability.rationale: Level 4: Medical records page with direct PDF download links was discoverable via a simple web search; no bot blocking, login, or portal required.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 3: Digitally-authored PDF (not a scan) is usable with annotation workarounds, and fax submission is available, but zero fillable fields means patients must print and handwrite.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized 15-section form with logical flow, clear numbered headers, and practical record-type checkboxes; minor issues with dense legal text on page 2 and cramped layout.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the form for self-access via the 'Personal' purpose checkbox, but the form was designed for third-party disclosures — patients must figure out how to list themselves as recipient and which sections apply.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: Vague '*fees may apply' notice without amounts or HIPAA cost-based limits, ambiguous witness signature line, and 'ALL APPLICABLE ENTRIES' language may go beyond what the law requires for patient access requests.

overall.summary: Scenic Mountain Medical Center provides an easy-to-find, well-organized authorization form in two languages with good scope controls, but the lack of a dedicated patient access pathway, non-fillable PDF format, and vague fee disclosure prevent it from reaching a patient-centered standard.
